data: Fast radio bursts are bright, unresolved, non-repeating, broadband, millisecond flashes, found primarily at high Galactic latitudes, with dispersion measures much larger than expected for a Galactic source 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7. The inferred all-sky burst rate 8 is comparable to the core-collapse supernova rate 9 out to redshift 0.5. If the observed dispersion measures are assumed to be dominated by the intergalactic medium, the sources are at cosmological distances with redshifts of 0.2 to 1 (refs 10 and 11). These parameters are consistent with a wide range of source models 12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 17. One fast burst 6 revealed circular polarization of the radio emission, but no linear polarization was detected, and hence no Faraday rotation measure could be determined. Here we report the examination of archival data revealing Faraday rotation in the fast radio burst FRB 110523. Its radio flux and dispersion measure are …
Dense magnetized plasma associated with a fast radio burst

Kiyoshi Masui and Hsiu-Hsien Lin and Jonathan Sievers and Christopher J Anderson and Tzu-Ching Chang and Xuelei Chen and Apratim Ganguly and Miranda Jarvis and Cheng-Yu Kuo and Yi-Chao Li and Yu-Wei Liao and Maura McLaughlin and Ue-Li Pen and Jeffrey B Peterson and Alexander Roman and Peter T Timbie and Tabitha Voytek and Jaswant K Yadav
